properties.media:imagetext:
(Family Letter No. 2)
Enroute Damascus-Istanbul
January 10, 1950
Dear Family,
We're now backtracking a bit - about 800 miles to be
more specific.
We had originally planned this one day in Constan-
tinople - a name you older ones will know better than Istanbul
but when I
found that there was a long waiting list of pay pass-
engers I
cancelled our trip.
However,
this morning the office
called up to say that a flood of cancellations had
come in and
there were empty seats so we decided to go.
They obviously told
the truth because there are three empty seats on the plane.
This morning in Damascus we visited the best shop in the
Bazaar.
Debby and Hebe shopped emid a million things which anyone
would crave while I went to
call on the American Consul - sort of
a command performance where there are few Americans.
He,
in common
with most other well informed, is worried over the Palestine quarrel
between the Jews and Arabs.
It is thought that no matter what
promises the Jews may make to the U.N. that they will not be sat-
isfied until they have taken all of Palestine.
Meanwhile,
the
Arabs of Palestine are trying to join what they have left of their
country to Trans-Jordan, calling the combination "Jordan".
Our
guide said that P.A.A.
was much dislikedin Syria a few years ago
because someone (probably T.W.A.) started a rumor: that all of our
officers, directors and pilots were Jews.
However, as in the case
of most over-done propaganda, it wasn't long before enough P.A.A.
personnel
passed through with names such as our steward, Angus
McPherson,
to convince the Syrians they had been misinformed.
There
are about 4,000,000 people in Syria of whom two-thirds are Moslem
and one-thira Christian; a very
few Jews, most of the latter having
gone to Israel.
This whole section of the world is like a smoul-
dering fire and may burst into flame at any time.
Istanbul
January 11, 1950
Istanbul.
We landed at about 10:00 p.m. and drove into
town with the P.A.A. No. 1.
He apologized for not getting us into
the best hotel,
but we are delighted with the Pera Palace.
Debby
and I have a red draped bedroom with a twelve foot ceiling; the
room is filled with German furniture of the 190's; a bathroom
larger than the average bedroom - slightly on the cold side on
account of because one window is broken and the paper in lieu of
glass is loose at the bottom; a living room done in brocade panels
with heavy framed Germanic paintings, four high windows complete
with heavy twelve foot arapes and more ponderous German furniture.
I'm sure that the Kaiser must have stayed here when he visited
Turkey in 1899.
(Found out later that he did! )
We're waiting now
for a car and
guide.
Outside it is snowing, but the snow melts as
it hits.
A string of cars moves by in constant procession three
floors below, and
each driver leans on the horn continually.
Debby says each minute is like New Year's Eve.
It's now 9:30 a.m.
and we're anxious to get going for if the plane from London is on
